slide.text:
Expanding indications for EUS & contrast enhanced harmonic EUS (CE-EUS)
EUS-FNA/B of hepatic lesions CE-EUS for evaluation and guidance of hepatic lesions

slide.title: Background
slide.notes:
The diagnosis of hepatic lesions has been traditionally accomplished by CT or US guidance.
Small lesions (<2 cm) and those that are difficult to differentiate from the background parenchyma are not easily accessible by percutaneous approach.
Although rare, complications from biopsy may include severe bleeding and implantation metastases in up to 3% of patients.
slide.notesNormalized:
the diagnosis of hepatic lesions has been traditionally accomplished by ct or us guidance.
small lesions (<2 cm) and those that are difficult to differentiate from the background parenchyma are not easily accessible by percutaneous approach.
although rare, complications from biopsy may include severe bleeding and implantation metastases in up to 3% of patients.
slide.notesHtml:
The diagnosis of hepatic lesions has been traditionally accomplished by CT or US guidance.

Small lesions (<2 cm) and those that are difficult to differentiate from the background parenchyma are not easily accessible by percutaneous approach.

Although rare, complications from biopsy may include severe bleeding and implantation metastases in up to 3% of patients.
slide.text:
Background The diagnosis of hepatic lesions has been traditionally accomplished by CT or US guidance.
Small lesions (<2 cm) and those that are difficult to differentiate from the background parenchyma are not easily accessible by percutaneous approach.
Endosc Ultrasound. 2015 Am J Gastroenterol. 2003 Gastroenterology. 1990

slide.title: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) and EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration (FNA) of liver lesions
slide.titleNormalized: endoscopic ultrasound (eus) and eus-guided fine-needle aspiration (fna) of liver lesions
slide.notes: 응우엔 reported that usefulness of EUS for evaluation of small hepatic lesions. 574 patients with GI and lung cancer underwent EUS for liver evaluation. 14 patients (2.4%) with focal liver lesions on EUS Before EUS, CT depicted liver lesions in only 3 of 14 (21%) patients. EUS can detect small focal liver lesions that are not detected at CT.
slide.notesNormalized: 응우엔 reported that usefulness of eus for evaluation of small hepatic lesions. 574 patients with gi and lung cancer underwent eus for liver evaluation. 14 patients (2.4%) with focal liver lesions on eus before eus, ct depicted liver lesions in only 3 of 14 (21%) patients. eus can detect small focal liver lesions that are not detected at ct.
slide.notesHtml:
응우엔 reported that usefulness of EUS for evaluation of small hepatic lesions.

574 patients with GI and lung cancer underwent EUS for liver evaluation.

14 patients (2.4%) with focal liver lesions on EUS

Before EUS, CT depicted liver lesions in only 3 of 14 (21%) patients.

EUS can detect small focal liver lesions that are not detected at CT.
slide.text:
574 patients with GI and lung cancer 14 patients (2.4%) with focal liver lesions on EUS Before EUS, CT depicted liver lesions in only 3 of 14 (21%) patients.
Gastrointest Endosc 1990

slide.titleNormalized: endoscopic ultrasound (eus) and eus-guided fine-needle aspiration (fna) of liver lesions
slide.notes: 응우엔 reported that usefulness of EUS for evaluation of small hepatic lesions. 574 patients with GI and lung cancer underwent EUS for liver evaluation. 14 patients (2.4%) with focal liver lesions on EUS Before EUS, CT depicted liver lesions in only 3 of 14 (21%) patients. EUS can detect small focal liver lesions that are not detected at CT.

slide.notesHtml:
응우엔 reported that usefulness of EUS for evaluation of small hepatic lesions.

574 patients with GI and lung cancer underwent EUS for liver evaluation.

14 patients (2.4%) with focal liver lesions on EUS

Before EUS, CT depicted liver lesions in only 3 of 14 (21%) patients.

EUS can detect small focal liver lesions that are not detected at CT.
slide.text:
Gastrointest Endosc 1990 EUS can detect small focal liver lesions that are not detected at CT
With EUS-FNA, it is possible to make a cytologic diagnosis of small liver metastasis

slide.title: Endoscopic Ultrasound Versus CT Scan for Detection of the Metastases to the liver
slide.titleNormalized: endoscopic ultrasound versus ct scan for detection of the metastases to the liver
slide.notes:
132 patients with GI and lung cancer 26 patients (19.7%) were identified with liver metastasis
EUS proved to be superior to CT scan in diagnostic accuracy, 98% compared to 92%. In its ability to detect the number of metastatic lesions in the liver, 40 compared to 19, respectively, (P = 0.008).
In comparison with the CT scan, there was trend in favor of EUS/EUS-FNA for the superior diagnostic accuracy. EUS was distinctly superior to the CT scan in detecting the number of metastatic lesions. EUS-FNA was also useful to identify the nature of lesions that were too small to be characterized on the CT scan.
slide.notesNormalized:
132 patients with gi and lung cancer 26 patients (19.7%) were identified with liver metastasis
eus proved to be superior to ct scan in diagnostic accuracy, 98% compared to 92%. in its ability to detect the number of metastatic lesions in the liver, 40 compared to 19, respectively, (p = 0.008).
in comparison with the ct scan, there was trend in favor of eus/eus-fna for the superior diagnostic accuracy. eus was distinctly superior to the ct scan in detecting the number of metastatic lesions. eus-fna was also useful to identify the nature of lesions that were too small to be characterized on the ct scan.
slide.notesHtml:
132 patients with GI and lung cancer

26 patients (19.7%) were identified with liver metastasis

EUS proved to be superior to CT scan in diagnostic accuracy, 98% compared to 92%.

In its ability to detect the number of metastatic lesions in the liver, 40 compared to 19, respectively, (P = 0.008).

In comparison with the CT scan, there was trend in favor of EUS/EUS-FNA for the superior diagnostic accuracy. EUS

was distinctly superior to the CT scan in detecting the number of metastatic lesions. EUS-FNA was also useful to

identify the nature of lesions that were too small to be characterized on the CT scan.
slide.text: 132 patients with GI and lung cancer 26 patients (19.7%) were identified with liver metastasis EUS was superior to CT scan in diagnostic accuracy, 98% compared to 92% (P = 0.0578) J Clin Gastroenterol 2009

slide.title: Endoscopic Ultrasound Versus CT Scan for Detection of the Metastases to the liver
slide.titleNormalized: endoscopic ultrasound versus ct scan for detection of the metastases to the liver
slide.notes:
132 patients with GI and lung cancer 26 patients (19.7%) were identified with liver metastasis
EUS proved to be superior to CT scan in diagnostic accuracy, 98% compared to 92%. In its ability to detect the number of metastatic lesions in the liver, 40 compared to 19, respectively, (P = 0.008).
In comparison with the CT scan, there was trend in favor of EUS/EUS-FNA for the superior diagnostic accuracy. EUS was distinctly superior to the CT scan in detecting the number of metastatic lesions. EUS-FNA was also useful to identify the nature of lesions that were too small to be characterized on the CT scan.
slide.notesNormalized:
132 patients with gi and lung cancer 26 patients (19.7%) were identified with liver metastasis
eus proved to be superior to ct scan in diagnostic accuracy, 98% compared to 92%. in its ability to detect the number of metastatic lesions in the liver, 40 compared to 19, respectively, (p = 0.008).
in comparison with the ct scan, there was trend in favor of eus/eus-fna for the superior diagnostic accuracy. eus was distinctly superior to the ct scan in detecting the number of metastatic lesions. eus-fna was also useful to identify the nature of lesions that were too small to be characterized on the ct scan.
slide.notesHtml:
132 patients with GI and lung cancer

26 patients (19.7%) were identified with liver metastasis

EUS proved to be superior to CT scan in diagnostic accuracy, 98% compared to 92%.

In its ability to detect the number of metastatic lesions in the liver, 40 compared to 19, respectively, (P = 0.008).

In comparison with the CT scan, there was trend in favor of EUS/EUS-FNA for the superior diagnostic accuracy. EUS

was distinctly superior to the CT scan in detecting the number of metastatic lesions. EUS-FNA was also useful to

identify the nature of lesions that were too small to be characterized on the CT scan.
slide.text: EUS detected significantly higher number of metastatic lesions in the liver (40 vs.19; P = 0.008). In 8 cases, CT detected lesions that were too small to characterize, of which EUS-FNA correctly diagnosed 4 cases to be malignant and 4 cases to be benign. J Clin Gastroenterol 2009

slide.notes: EUS-FNB with core biopsy needle for solid liver mass may be helpful in the management of patients who are unable to diagnose using percutaneous liver biopsy.
slide.notesNormalized: eus-fnb with core biopsy needle for solid liver mass may be helpful in the management of patients who are unable to diagnose using percutaneous liver biopsy.
slide.notesHtml:
EUS-FNB with core biopsy needle for solid liver mass may be helpful in the

management of patients who are unable to diagnose using percutaneous liver biopsy.
slide.text: J Gastroenterol Hepatol 2015

slide.title: Endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration can target right liver mass
slide.titleNormalized: endoscopic ultrasound-guided fine-needle aspiration can target right liver mass
slide.text: Between Sep 2010 and July 2016 A single center retrospective study Clinical utility of EUS-FNA for hepatic lesions 47 consecutive pts with hepatic masses underwent EUS-FNA

slide.title: RESULTS (I)
slide.text: RESULTS (I) Characteristics N = 47 Site of biopsy, n (%) Left lobe 30 (63.8) Right lobe 17 (36.2) Size of lesion on EUS, median, mm (IQR) 26 (15–37) Indications for EUS‑FNA, n (%) Concurrent FNA for pancreatic and liver lesions 16 (34) EUS‑FNA after failure of percutaneous liver biopsy 13 (27.7) Liver mass to assess primary lesion 12 (25.5) Contraindication of percutaneous liver biopsy due to advanced liver cirrhosis 6 (12.8) Number of needle passes, median (IQR) 3 (3–4) Technical success, n (%) 46 (97.9) Sample adequacy, n (%) 42/46 (91.3) Diagnostic accuracy, n (%) 38 (80.9) Adverse events, n (%) 0

slide.title: RESULTS (II)
slide.text: RESULTS (II)

slide.title: Limitation of EUS-FNA/B
slide.text:
Limitation of EUS-FNA/B Difficult to get anatomical orientation Penetration depth Angulation of scope tip
A thorough understanding of the liver anatomy is prerequisite for successful EUS-FNA/B for hepatic lesions

Expanding indications for EUS & contrast enhanced harmonic EUS (CE-EUS)
EUS-FNA/B of hepatic lesions CE-EUS for evaluation and guidance of hepatic lesions

slide.title: SonoVueTM vs SonazoidTM
slide.notes: Two kinds of second generation agents including SONOVUE and SONAZOID are available in Korea. Two agents are equivalent for detectability of arterial vascularity Sonazoid is phagocytosed by Kupffer cells in liver which enables Kupffer cell image persistent and stable image enhancement
slide.notesNormalized: two kinds of second generation agents including sonovue and sonazoid are available in korea. two agents are equivalent for detectability of arterial vascularity sonazoid is phagocytosed by kupffer cells in liver which enables kupffer cell image persistent and stable image enhancement
slide.notesHtml:
Two kinds of second generation agents including SONOVUE and SONAZOID are available in Korea.

Two agents are equivalent for detectability of arterial vascularity

Sonazoid is phagocytosed by Kupffer cells in liver which enables Kupffer cell image persistent and stable image enhancement
slide.text: SonoVueTM vs SonazoidTM Detectability of arterial vascularity Both, equivalent (for evaluation of pancreas) Kupffer cell image of Sonazoid Phagocytosed by Kupffer cells in liver Kupffer cell activity: related to differentiation Persistent and stable image enhancement Preferable for evaluation of liver lesion

slide.title: Kupffer Cell Image in CE-EUS
slide.notes: Sonazoid persist longer in the liver parenchyma compared to pancreas Prolonged visualization of malignant nodules-> inte Vascular, kupffer rvention guidance for liver lesions
slide.notesNormalized: sonazoid persist longer in the liver parenchyma compared to pancreas prolonged visualization of malignant nodules-> inte vascular, kupffer rvention guidance for liver lesions
slide.notesHtml:
Sonazoid persist longer in the liver parenchyma compared to pancreas

Prolonged visualization of malignant nodules-> inte

Vascular, kupffer

rvention guidance for liver lesions
slide.text: Kupffer Cell Image in CE-EUS Prolonged visualization of malignant nodules-> increased detectability & aid for intervention in liver

slide.title: Contrast-enhanced harmonic image
slide.text:
Contrast-enhanced harmonic image Kupffer image in contrast-enhanced US remarkably increased the detectability of liver lesions, compared with B-mode US.
The accuracy of diagnosis of liver metastases under contrast-enhanced US has been reported to be more than 90%. Sugimoto K, et al. Acad Radiol 2009 Dietrich CF, et al. World J Gastroenterol 2006

slide.title: RESULTS (I)
slide.text: RESULTS (I) Variables B-mode EUS CE-EUS Lesion identification 22 (73.3%) 29 (96.7%) Suspected 8 (26.7%) 1 (3.3%) Faintly visible 15 (50%) 0 Clearly visible 7 (23.3%) 29 *96.7%) Visuality score, median 2 (1-2.25) 3 (3-3) Visualization of Hepatic lesions with CE-EUS

slide.title: RESULTS (II)
slide.notes: The diagnostic accuracy of CH EUS guided FNA was 97%
slide.notesNormalized: the diagnostic accuracy of ch eus guided fna was 97%
slide.notesHtml: The diagnostic accuracy of CH EUS guided FNA was 97%
slide.text: Sensitivity Specificity Diagnostic accuracy CE-EUS 78.6% 100% 80% CE-EUS + CE-EUS guided FNA 96.4% 100% 97% RESULTS (II) The sensitivity and specificity of CE-EUS

slide.title: RESULTS (III)
slide.text: Variables SonVueTM (n=16) SonazoidTM (n=14) Lesion identification 15 (93.8%) 14 (100%) Adequacy 14 (87.5%) 14 (100%) Diagnostic accuracy 15 (93.8%) 14 (100%) Number of needle pass 3 (IQR 3-4) 2.5 (IQR 1-3) RESULTS (III) Comparison of contrast agents

slide.title: 46-y/o-male, suspected pancreatic cancer with liver metastasis
slide.titleNormalized: 46-y/o-male, suspected pancreatic cancer with liver metastasis
slide.notes: B mode EUS shows subtle heterogeneous echogenicity, but it is not clear. After contrast inj, multiple hypoenhanced mass were clearly visualized. Therefore, FNA can be easily performed. CHEUS is preferred tech in cases with pancreatic and liver lesions
slide.notesNormalized: b mode eus shows subtle heterogeneous echogenicity, but it is not clear. after contrast inj, multiple hypoenhanced mass were clearly visualized. therefore, fna can be easily performed. cheus is preferred tech in cases with pancreatic and liver lesions
slide.notesHtml:
B mode EUS shows subtle heterogeneous echogenicity, but it is not clear.

After contrast inj, multiple hypoenhanced mass were clearly visualized. Therefore, FNA can be easily performed.

CHEUS is preferred tech in cases with pancreatic and liver lesions

slide.title: CE-EUS guided Liver FNA
slide.text: CE-EUS guided Liver FNA CE-EUS guided FNA can result in a high diagnostic accuracy in cases where the hepatic lesions are poorly visible on B-mode EUS.

slide.title: Limitation of CE-EUS guided FNA
slide.notes: Helpful in selected cases as a problem-solving tool
slide.notesNormalized: helpful in selected cases as a problem-solving tool
slide.notesHtml: Helpful in selected cases as a problem-solving tool
slide.text: Limitation of CE-EUS guided FNA Affected by sonic attenuation (deep seated lesion, severe fatty liver). Penetration of US beam with CE-EUS is inferior.

slide.title: Conclusion
slide.notes: EUS may be more sensitive for identifying smaller liver lesions. EUS-FNA is possible to perform diagnostic assessment and could improve tumor stating as well as tissue acquisition. EUS-FNA can be used as a rescue method in cases where the percutaneous approach failed.
slide.notesNormalized: eus may be more sensitive for identifying smaller liver lesions. eus-fna is possible to perform diagnostic assessment and could improve tumor stating as well as tissue acquisition. eus-fna can be used as a rescue method in cases where the percutaneous approach failed.
slide.notesHtml:
EUS may be more sensitive for identifying smaller liver lesions.

EUS-FNA is possible to perform diagnostic assessment and could improve tumor stating as well as tissue acquisition.

EUS-FNA can be used as a rescue method in cases where the percutaneous approach failed.
slide.text: Conclusion More sensitive for identifying smaller liver lesions. EUS-FNA is possible to perform diagnostic assessment and could improve tumor staging as well as tissue acquisition. A rescue method in cases where the percutaneous approach failed or contraindicated.

slide.title: Conclusion
slide.notes: Helpful in selected cases as a problem-solving tool
slide.notesNormalized: helpful in selected cases as a problem-solving tool
slide.notesHtml: Helpful in selected cases as a problem-solving tool
slide.text: Conclusion One session of EUS-FNA for suspected pancreatic and liver lesions. Increases the detectability of inconspicuous liver mass on B-mode EUS. A problem-solving tool in cases where conventional EUS had failed to localize the tumor.
